stk.ga.input module¶

Defines classes which deal with input.

class stk.ga.input.GAInput(input_file)¶

Bases: object

A class for reading a GA’s input file.

An stk input file is a Python script. The script must define a set of variables. Each variable defines a parameter or a function used by the GA. If the variable defines a function, it must also define any parameters necessary to use the function. It does not have to define any default initialized parameters, though it may if desired.

Each variable name defined in the input file must corresond to an attribute of this class.

Variables which define a function or method are supplied as dictionaries, for example:

fitness_func = {'NAME' : 'func_name',
                'param1_name' : param1_val,
                'param2_name' : param2_val}

Key points from the line example are:

  1. The variable name (e.g. fitness_func) specifies the GA operation and matches the name of an attribute of GAInput.
  2. The key 'NAME' holds the name of the function which carries out the GA operation. Note the difference between the variable name specifying the generic role, i.e. a fitness function, versus the value for 'NAME' holding the name of the function which carries out that role.
  3. Any parameters which the function needs are provided as key value pairs where the keys are strings holding the parameter name.

Valid functions for a given role are described in the corresponding attribute of GAInput.

Some variables will need to define other parameters used by the GA such as constants or lists of constants,

num_generations = 5
databases = ['first/path', 'second/path']
processes¶

The number of parallel processes to create when running parallel operations. This does not have to be specified in the input file. If not specified, the number will default to the value returned by psutil.cpu_count().

# some_input_file.py

# Use 4 cores.
processes = 4
Type:int
pop_size : int

The size of the population.

# some_input_file.py

# GA will have a population size of 25.
pop_size = 25
num_generations : int

The number of generations the GA runs for.

# some_input_file.py

# GA run for 50 generations.
pop_size = 50
num_mutations: int

The number of mutation operations carried out per generation.

# some_input_file.py

# Carry out 5 mutation operations each generation.
num_mutations = 5
num_crossovers: int

The number of crossover operations carried out per generation.

# some_input_file.py

# Carry out 3 crossover operations each generation.
num_crossovers = 3
init_func : dict

This must define the parameters of a GAPopulation initializer.

# some_input_file.py

# Use Population.init_random to initialize the GA pop.

# Load the StructUnits used to build the initial population
# from a folder.
amines2 = [stk.StructUnit2(filename, 'amine')
           for filename in iglob('path/amine2/*.mol')]
aldehydes3 = [stk.StructUnit3(filename, 'aldehyde')
              for filename
              in iglob('path/aldehyde3/*.mol')]
# Topologies used to construct the initial population.
topologies = [stk.FourPlusSix(), stk.EightPlusTwelve(),
              stk.Dodecahedron(), stk.TwoPlusThree()]

# Define the initialization function and its parameters.
init_func = {'NAME': 'init_random',
             'macromol_class': stk.Cage,
             'building_blocks': [amines, aldehydes],
             'topologies': topologies}
generational_select_func : dict

This must define the parameters of a Selection method. This will be the function used to select members of the next generation.

# some_input_file.py

generational_select_func = {'NAME': 'stochastic_sampling',
                            'use_rank': True}
crossover_select_func : dict

This must define the parameters of a Selection method. This will be the function used to select molecules for crossover.

# some_input_file.py

crossover_select_func = {'NAME': 'crossover_roulette',
                         'truncation': 5}
mutation_select_func : dict

This must define the parameters of a Selection method. This will be the function used to select molecules for mutation.

# some_input_file.py

mutation_select_func = {'NAME': 'stochastic_sampling',
                        'truncation': 3,
                        'duplicates': True}
crossover_funcs : list of dict

This list holds a dict for each crossover function which is to be used by the GA. The functions are defined as methods in Crossover

# some_input_file.py

crossover_fn1 = {
    'NAME': 'genetic_recombination',
    'key': lambda x: x.func_grp.name
}

crossover_fn2 = {
    'NAME': 'jumble',
    'n_offspring_building_blocks': 2,
    'n_offspring': 3
}

crossover_funcs = [crossover_fn1, crossover_fn2]
mutation_funcs : list of dict

This list holds a dict for each mutation function which is to be used by the GA. The functions are defined as methods in Mutation

# some_input_file.py

# mutation_func1 substitutes the amine building block in
# the molecule with one from the list "amines".

amines2 = [stk.StructUnit2(filename, 'amine')
           for filename in iglob('path/amine2/*.mol')]

mutation_fn1 = {
    'NAME': 'random_bb',
    'mols': amines,
    'key': lambda x: x.func_grp.name == 'amine'}

# mutation_func2 substitutes the aldehyde building block in
# the molecule with one from the list "aldehydes".

aldehydes3 = [stk.StructUnit3(filename, 'aldehyde')
              for filename
              in iglob('path/aldehyde3/*.mol')]

mutation_fn2 = {
    'NAME': 'random_bb',
    'mols': aldehydes,
    'key': lambda x: x.func_grp.name == 'aldehyde'}

mutation_funcs = [mutation_fn1, mutation_fn2]
opt_func : dict

This must define the parameters of a function defined in optimization. This will be the function used to optimize the structures of the molecules.

opt_func = {'NAME': 'rdkit_ETKDG'}
fitness_func : dict, function

This must define the parameters of a function defined in fitness. This will be the function used to calculate the fitness of the molecules.

Alternatively a fitness function can be defined directly in the input file, for example:

# some_input_file.py

def custom_fitness_fn(macro_mol):
    energy = macro_mol.energy.rdkit('mmff')
    diameter = macro_mol.max_diameter()[0]
    return energy + diameter

fitness_func = custom_fitness_fn

The function must conform to all the guidelines specified in fitness. It is important that the fitness function is defined with its own name, such as custom_fitness_fn. DO NOT DO THIS:

# some_input_file.py

def fitness_func(macro_mol):
    energy = macro_mol.energy.rdkit('mmff')
    diameter = macro_mol.max_diameter()[0]
    return energy + diameter

If you have two different input files, and each defines the input function as fitness_func, then even if they do completely different things, stk will think they are the same function. Therefore, if you load a molecule produced by the GA using the first input file, into a GA run using the second input file, the molecule’s fitness value will not be recalculated in the second run - even if you changed the internals of the fitness function. The only way to ensure that the fitness value is recalculated is if different fitness functions have different names.

exit_func : dict

This must define the parameters of a method of Exit. This will be the function which checks if an early exit criterion has been satisfied. If missing, the default is Exit.no_exit().

# some_input_file.py

# Stop the GA when the top 5 molecules are the same
# for 15 generations.
exit_func = {
    'NAME': 'fitness_plateau',
    'num_gens': 15,
    'top_members': 5
}
mutation_weights : list of float

The probability that each function in mutation_funcs will be selected each time a mutation operation is carried out. The order of the probabilities corresponds to the order of the mutation functions in mutation_funcs.

# some_input_file.py

mutations_funcs = [fn1, fn2, fn3]
# Use fn1 for mutations 50 % of the time fn2 for mutations
# 20 % of the time and fn3 for 30 % of the time.
mutation_weights = [0.5, 0.2, 0.3]
crossover_weights : list of float

The probability that each function in crossover_funcs will be selected each time a crossover operation is carried out. The order of the probabilities corresponds to the order of the crossover functions in crossover_funcs.

# some_input_fn.py

crossover_fn = [fn1, fn2, fn3, fn4]
# When doing crossover operations, use fn1 25 % of the
# time, fn2 10 % of the time, fn3 25 % of the time and
# fn4 40 % of the time.
crossover_weights = [0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 0.4]
normalization_funcs : list of dict

This list holds a dict for each normalization function used to rescale or normalize the population’s fitness values. The order reflects the order in which they are applied each generation. The functions are defined as methods in Normalization. This can be ommited from the input file which means that no normalization functions will be used.

# some_input_file.py

norm_func0 = {'NAME': 'cage',
              'cavity': 50,
              'window': 50}

# First shift all energy
# values so that they are always positive.
norm_func1 = {'NAME': 'shift_elements',
                      'indices': [3]}

# Second, make sure that the magnitudes
# of all fitness parameters are comparable.
norm_func2 = {'NAME': 'magnitudes'}

# Third, combine the fitness
# parameter into a single fitness value.
norm_func3 = {'NAME': 'combine',
              'coefficients': [1, 0, 0.5, 0, 0, 0],
              'exponents': [1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1]}

# Last, invert the fitness value because all
# fitness parameters are inversely proportional to fitness.
norm_func4 = {'NAME': 'invert'}

# Tell the GA which normalizaion function to use.
normalization_funcs = [norm_func0,
                       norm_func1,
                       norm_func2,
                       norm_func3,
                       norm_func4]

Normalization functions can also be defined directly in the input file, see fitness_func.

databases : list of str

A list which holds the paths to any number JSON files. These files must hold the JSON representations of dumped Population instances. All the molecules in the populations are loaded into memory for the duration of the GA run. Molecules loaded in this way do not have to be built, re-optimized or have fitness values recalculated when encountered by the GA.

# some_input_file.py

databases = ['path/to/some/population1.json',
             'path/to/some/other/population2.json']
progress_dump : bool

If True a .json Population dump is made at the end of the GA run called progress.json. The population holds each generation made by the GA as a subpopulation. This can be ommitted from the input file, in which case it defaults to True.

# some_input_file.py

# Do not make a population holding every generation
# of the GA.
progress_dump = False
database_dump : bool

If True a .json Population dump is made at the end of the GA run called database.json. The population holds every molecule made by the GA during its run. This can be omitted from the input file, in which case it defaults to True.

# some_input_file.py

# Do not save all the molecules made by the GA.
database_dump = False
plot_epp : bool or str

If a string is provided, it should hold the base name for the EPP plots made by the GA. If False then no EPP plots are made. This can be omitted from the input file, in which case it defaults to 'epp.png'.

# some_input_file.py

# Do not plot the EPP.
plot_epp = False
logging_level : int

The logging level for logging messages to the screen. This can be omitted from the input file in which case it defulats to logging.DEBUG.

# some_input_file.py

# Log only messages with level WARNING or higher.
import logging
logging_level = logging.WARNING
counters : bool

If True plots of which molecules get chosen by selection functions are made. This can be omitted from the input file, in which case it defaults to True.

# some_input_file.py

# Do not plot the frequency at which molecules are
# selected for GA operations.
counters = False
pop_dumps : bool

If True each generation makes a .json dump file. This can be omitted from the input file, in which case it defaults to True. It means that a progress and database dump is made at each generation as well.

# some_input_file.py

# Turn of debug population dumps.
progress_dump = False
tar_output : bool

If True a copy of the output folder is compressed, tarred and placed in the output folder. This can be omitted from the input file, in which case it defaults to True.

# some_input_file.py

# Do not make a tar.gz file of the output folder.
tar_output = False
progress_load : str

The path to a progress.json file generated by a previous GA run. This means the previous GA progress is restored and a restart GA run can be performed. Can be omitted from the input file in which case it dafaults to ''. This means that a new GA run is assumed.

# some_input_file.py

# Load the state of a previous GA run.
progress_load = 'path/to/some/progress.json'
crosser()¶

Use input file data to build Crossover instance.

Returns:A Crossover instance which has all of the crossover related data held by the GAInput instance.
Return type:Crossover
exiter()¶

Use input file data to build Exit instance.

Returns:An Exit instance loaded with the exit function defined in the input file.
Return type:Exit
fitnessor()¶

Use input file data to extract fitness function information.

Returns:A FunctionData object which represents the fitness function.
Return type:FunctionData
ga_tools()¶

Use input file data to build a GATools instance.

Returns:A GATools instance built from the information defined in the input file.
Return type:GATools
initer()¶

Use input file to extract initialization function information.

Returns:A FunctionData object which represents the initialization function.
Return type:FunctionData
mutator()¶

Use input file data to build Mutation instance.

Returns:A Mutation instance which has all of the mutation related data held in the input file.
Return type:Mutation
normalizer()¶

Use input file data to build Normalization instance.

Returns:A Normalization instance which has all of the normalization related data held in the input file.
Return type:Normalization
opter()¶

Use the input file to extract optimization function data.

Returns:A FunctionData object which represents the optimization function defined in the input file.
Return type:FunctionData
selector()¶

Use input file data to build Selection instance.

Returns:A Selection instance which has all of the selection related data held in the input file.
Return type:Selection
